title: Welcome To My Blog
text:

Since this post doesn’t specify an explicit image, the first image in the post will be used in the listing page of posts.

title: Academic Work
text:
Other Projects
Some other projects that I’ve led:






How collective existential threat is implicated in the mental representations of immigrants and Americans. Brief overview. Talk.









The role of implicit and explicit group representations in trusting outgroup members. Brief overview.



Jan Voelkel and I created a Shiny web app that people can use to explore the results for the Strengthening Democracy Challenge. Check it out here.

title: Isaias Ghezae
text:
I’m a Research Coordinator at the Polarization and Social Change Lab at Stanford University and a Research Affiliate at the Center for the Science of Moral Understanding.
I graduated from the University of California, Santa Barbara in June 2022 with a B.S. in Psychological & Brain Sciences, where I was a Goldwater Scholar and a McNair Scholar.
While at UC Santa Barbara I mainly worked with Dr. Daniel Conroy-Beam and Dr. Hongbo Yu. I spent a summer as a BrainWAVE Fellow at Caltech’s Tianqiao and Chrissy Chen Institute for Neuroscience, working with Dr. Colin Camerer and his Behavioral and Neuroeconomics Group. I was also a 2021 participant in the Society for Personality and Social Psychology’s SPUR program.

title: About Me
text:
I’m a Research Coordinator at the Polarization and Social Change Lab at Stanford University and a Research Affiliate at the Center for the Science of Moral Understanding.
I graduated from the University of California, Santa Barbara in June 2022 with a B.S. in Psychological & Brain Sciences, where I was a Goldwater Scholar and a McNair Scholar.
While at UC Santa Barbara I mainly worked with Dr. Daniel Conroy-Beam and Dr. Hongbo Yu. I spent a summer as a BrainWAVE Fellow at Caltech’s Tianqiao and Chrissy Chen Institute for Neuroscience, working with Dr. Colin Camerer and his Behavioral and Neuroeconomics Group. I was also a 2021 participant in the Society for Personality and Social Psychology’s SPUR program.
